docs.title: Get an overview

docs.text: Create a PHP file with any name in the src/Profiles folder. In the example, the file is called TestPseudonymizeProfile.php . The file will have the following content: <?php declare(strict_types=1); namespace Waldhacker\Pseudify\Profiles; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Model\Pseudonymize\TableDefinition; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Pseudonymize\ProfileInterface; class TestPseudonymizeProfile implements ProfileInterface { public function getIdentifier(): string { return 'test-profile'; } public function getTableDefinition(): TableDefinition { $tableDefinition = new TableDefinition(identifier: $this->getIdentifier()); return $tableDefinition; } } The getIdentifier() method must return a unique identifier of your profile and should only consist of letters, numbers or the characters - and _ and must not contain any spaces. After the profile has been created, the cache must be cleared. $ docker run -it -v $(pwd):/data \ ghcr.io/waldhacker/pseudify cache:clear The command pseudify pseudify:debug:pseudonymize test-profile already gives you (empty) information about your profile. $ pseudify pseudify:debug:pseudonymize test-profile Pseudonymization profile "test-profile" ======================================= Pseudonymize data in this tables -------------------------------- ------- -------- --------------- ------------------- Table column data decoders data manipulators ------- -------- --------------- -------------------
docs.title: Create a "Profile"

docs.text: We start by modelling the scalar database data. To do this, you extend the getTableDefinition() method in the profile. <?php declare(strict_types=1); namespace Waldhacker\Pseudify\Profiles; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Model\Pseudonymize\Column; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Model\Pseudonymize\TableDefinition; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Pseudonymize\ProfileInterface; class TestPseudonymizeProfile implements ProfileInterface { public function getIdentifier(): string { return 'test-profile'; } public function getTableDefinition(): TableDefinition { $tableDefinition = new TableDefinition(identifier: $this->getIdentifier()); $tableDefinition ->addTable(table: 'wh_user', columns: [ Column::create(identifier: 'username'), Column::create(identifier: 'password'), Column::create(identifier: 'first_name'), Column::create(identifier: 'last_name'), Column::create(identifier: 'email'), Column::create(identifier: 'city'), ]) ->addTable(table: 'wh_log', columns: [ Column::create(identifier: 'ip'), ]) ; return $tableDefinition; } } With the method addTable() you tell pseudify that you want to model a database table. In the parameter columns one or more database columns can be modelled ( Column::create() ). The command pseudify pseudify:debug:pseudonymize test-profile displays the modelled database columns under pseudonymize data in this tables . Under data decoders is scalar , which means that the data is not decoded during the pseudonymisation. $ pseudify pseudify:debug:pseudonymize test-profile Pseudonymization profile "test-profile" ======================================= Pseudonymize data in this tables -------------------------------- --------- --------------------- --------------- ------------------- Table column data decoders data manipulators --------- --------------------- --------------- ------------------- wh_user username (string) Scalar wh_user password (string) Scalar wh_user first_name (string) Scalar wh_user last_name (string) Scalar wh_user email (string) Scalar wh_user city (string) Scalar wh_log ip (string) Scalar --------- --------------------- --------------- -------------------
docs.title: Pseudonymise data of a database column

docs.text: As already learned in the chapter "Searching encoded data" , it can happen that data in database columns are in encoded form. This means that the encoded plaintext must be decoded before pseudonymisation and encoded again after pseudonymisation. In our example, the database column log_message of the table wh_log and the database column session_data_json of the table wh_user_session contain encoded data in JSON format. The database column session_data of the table wh_user_session contains encoded data in the form of serialised PHP data. You have to find out how this data is encoded by looking at the source code or the documentation of the application that uses the database. In order for pseudify to pseudonymise the data, the data must first be decoded. To do this, the data type (parameter dataType ) must be passed to the definition of a database column ( Column::create() ). <?php declare(strict_types=1); namespace Waldhacker\Pseudify\Profiles; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Model\Pseudonymize\Column; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Model\Pseudonymize\TableDefinition; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Pseudonymize\ProfileInterface; class TestPseudonymizeProfile implements ProfileInterface { public function getIdentifier(): string { return 'test-profile'; } public function getTableDefinition(): TableDefinition { $tableDefinition = new TableDefinition(identifier: $this->getIdentifier()); $tableDefinition // ... ->addTable(table: 'wh_log', columns: [ // ... Column::create(identifier: 'log_message', dataType: Column::DATA_TYPE_JSON), ]) ->addTable(table: 'wh_user_session', columns: [ Column::create(identifier: 'session_data', dataType: Column::DATA_TYPE_SERIALIZED), Column::create(identifier: 'session_data_json', dataType: Column::DATA_TYPE_JSON), ]) ; return $tableDefinition; } } The method Column::create() can be passed with the parameter dataType a name of a built-in decoder . This is equivalent to ->setEncoder(encoder: new JsonEncoder()) or ->setEncoder(encoder: new SerializedEncoder()) : <?php declare(strict_types=1); namespace Waldhacker\Pseudify\Profiles; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Processor\Encoder\JsonEncoder; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Processor\Encoder\SerializedEncoder; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Model\Pseudonymize\Column; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Model\Pseudonymize\TableDefinition; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Pseudonymize\ProfileInterface; class TestPseudonymizeProfile implements ProfileInterface { public function getIdentifier(): string { return 'test-profile'; } public function getTableDefinition(): TableDefinition { $tableDefinition = new TableDefinition(identifier: $this->getIdentifier()); $tableDefinition // ... ->addTable(table: 'wh_log', columns: [ // ... Column::create(identifier: 'log_message')->setEncoder(encoder: new JsonEncoder()), ]) ->addTable(table: 'wh_user_session', columns: [ Column::create(identifier: 'session_data')->setEncoder(encoder: new SerializedEncoder()), Column::create(identifier: 'session_data_json')->setEncoder(encoder: new JsonEncoder()), ]) ; return $tableDefinition; } } The command pseudify pseudify:debug:pseudonymize test-profile now displays the just modelled database columns under pseudonymize data in this tables . Under data decoders the just defined decoders are listed ( Json / Serialised ). pseudify pseudify:debug:pseudonymize test-profile Pseudonymization profile "test-profile" ======================================= Pseudonymize data in this tables -------------------------------- ----------------- -------------------------- --------------- ------------------- Table column data decoders data manipulators ----------------- -------------------------- --------------- ------------------- wh_user username (string) Scalar wh_user password (string) Scalar wh_user first_name (string) Scalar wh_user last_name (string) Scalar wh_user email (string) Scalar wh_user city (string) Scalar wh_log ip (string) Scalar wh_log log_message (text) Json wh_user_session session_data (blob) Serialized wh_user_session session_data_json (text) Json ----------------- -------------------------- --------------- -------------------
docs.title: Encoded database columns

docs.text: As already learned in the chapter "Searching multiple encoded data" , it can happen that data in database columns are stored in multiple encoded form. In our example, the database column meta_data of the table wh_meta_data contains multiple encoded data. In order for pseudify to pseudonymise the data, the data must first be converted from hexadecimal representation form to binary format and then the binary data must still be decompressed from ZLIB format. To perform multiple decoding, the ChainedEncoder can be used. With the ChainedEncoder, several decoders can be configured, which then decode the data in sequence. <?php declare(strict_types=1); namespace Waldhacker\Pseudify\Profiles; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Processor\Encoder\ChainedEncoder; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Processor\Encoder\GzEncodeEncoder; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Processor\Encoder\HexEncoder; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Model\Pseudonymize\Column; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Model\Pseudonymize\TableDefinition; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Pseudonymize\ProfileInterface; class TestPseudonymizeProfile implements ProfileInterface { public function getIdentifier(): string { return 'test-profile'; } public function getTableDefinition(): TableDefinition { $tableDefinition = new TableDefinition(identifier: $this->getIdentifier()); $tableDefinition // ... ->addTable(table: 'wh_meta_data', columns: [ Column::create(identifier: 'meta_data')->setEncoder(encoder: new ChainedEncoder(encoders: [ new HexEncoder(), new GzEncodeEncoder(defaultContext: [ GzEncodeEncoder::ENCODE_LEVEL => 5, GzEncodeEncoder::ENCODE_ENCODING => ZLIB_ENCODING_GZIP, ]), ])), ]) ; return $tableDefinition; } } When pseudonymising the database column meta_data of the table wh_meta_data , pseudify will then first process the data of the database column using the method decode() of HexEncoder and then by the decode() method of the GzEncodeEncoder , so that the result can then be pseudonymised. Afterwards, pseudify will process the pseudonymised data using the encode() method of the GzEncodeEncoder and then process it using the encode() method of the HexEncoder and write it back to the database. pseudify pseudify:debug:pseudonymize test-profile Pseudonymization profile "test-profile" ======================================= Pseudonymize data in this tables -------------------------------- ----------------- -------------------------- --------------- ------------------- Table column data decoders data manipulators ----------------- -------------------------- --------------- ------------------- wh_user username (string) Scalar wh_user password (string) Scalar wh_user first_name (string) Scalar wh_user last_name (string) Scalar wh_user email (string) Scalar wh_user city (string) Scalar wh_log ip (string) Scalar wh_log log_message (text) Json wh_user_session session_data (blob) Serialized wh_user_session session_data_json (text) Json wh_meta_data meta_data (blob) Hex<>GzEncode ----------------- -------------------------- --------------- ------------------- You will now see under Pseudonymize data in these tables that the names Hex<>GzEncode are listed under data decoders of the database column wh_meta_data . This signals to you that the data will first be decoded using the HexEncoder and then using the GzEncodeEncoder.
docs.title: Multiple encoded database columns

docs.text: As already learned in the chapter "Searching differently encoded data" , it can happen that data in database columns are stored in differently encoded form. Based on conditions, applications store the data in different formats. In our example, the data in the database column log_data of the table wh_log is serialised PHP data, which has been encoded in Base64 format and then stored in hexadecimal form if the database column log_type contains the value bar . The data of the database column log_data are in JSON format, which were stored in hexadecimal form if the database column log_type contains the value foo . In both cases ( log_type == foo and log_type == bar ) the data can first be converted from hexadecimal representation to binary format. The further decodings must be modelled manually: <?php declare(strict_types=1); namespace Waldhacker\Pseudify\Profiles; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Processor\Encoder\Base64Encoder; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Processor\Encoder\ChainedEncoder; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Processor\Encoder\GzEncodeEncoder; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Processor\Encoder\HexEncoder; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Processor\Encoder\JsonEncoder; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Processor\Processing\DataProcessing; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Processor\Processing\Pseudonymize\DataManipulatorContext; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Model\Pseudonymize\Column; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Model\Pseudonymize\TableDefinition; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Pseudonymize\ProfileInterface; class TestPseudonymizeProfile implements ProfileInterface { public function getIdentifier(): string { return 'test-profile'; } public function getTableDefinition(): TableDefinition { $tableDefinition = new TableDefinition(identifier: $this->getIdentifier()); $tableDefinition // ... ->addTable(table: 'wh_log', columns: [ // ... Column::create(identifier: 'log_data', dataType: Column::DATA_TYPE_HEX) ->addDataProcessing(dataProcessing: new DataProcessing(identifier: 'process logs', processor: function (DataManipulatorContext $context): void { $row = $context->getDatebaseRow(); if ('foo' === $row['log_type']) { $encoder = new ChainedEncoder(encoders: [new Base64Encoder(), new JsonEncoder()]); } else if ('bar' === $row['log_type']) { $encoder = new SerializedEncoder(); } else { return; } $logData = $encoder->decode(data: $context->getDecodedData()); // pseudonymize the data // ... } )), ]) // ... ; return $tableDefinition; } } With the method addDataProcessing() , further manual data transformations can be programmed in addition to the decoding of the data. The DataProcessings are executed after the decoding of the data. Any number of DataProcessings can be defined, which are processed one after the other. A DataProcessing consists of a unique identification per database column (parameter identifier ) and an anonymous function (parameter processor ). The anonymous function is called with a parameter context of the type DataManipulatorContext . The DataManipulatorContext can be used to obtain various information about the data set to be processed: $context->getRawData() : The original data of the database column. $context->getDecodedData() : The data of the column after decoding $context->getDatebaseRow() : Contains the original data of all columns of the row being processed $context->getProcessedData() : Contains the processed data set by $context->setProcessedData() , otherwise the data of the database column after decoding. In our example, we use the value of the database column log_type to determine how the data must be further decoded. If the value of log_type is foo , the data is decoded using the Base64Encoder() and then using the JsonEncoder(). If the value of log_type is bar , the data is decoded using the SerializedEncoder(). The data is now decoded and can then be pseudonymised. pseudify pseudify:debug:pseudonymize test-profile Pseudonymization profile "test-profile" ======================================= Pseudonymize data in this tables -------------------------------- ----------------- -------------------------- --------------- ------------------- Table column data decoders data manipulators ----------------- -------------------------- --------------- ------------------- wh_user username (string) Scalar wh_user password (string) Scalar wh_user first_name (string) Scalar wh_user last_name (string) Scalar wh_user email (string) Scalar wh_user city (string) Scalar wh_log ip (string) Scalar wh_log log_message (text) Json wh_log log_data (blob) Hex process logs wh_user_session session_data (blob) Serialized wh_user_session session_data_json (text) Json wh_meta_data meta_data (blob) Hex<>GzEncode ----------------- -------------------------- --------------- -------------------
docs.title: Differently encoded database columns

docs.text: Pseudonymisation is implemented at column level using the method addDataProcessing() . In the chapter differently encoded database columns the DataProcessings have already been described. In a DataProcessing not only a possibly required extended decoding / encoding of the data takes place, but above all the pseudonymisation itself. Each defined database column ( Column::create() ) needs at least one DataProcessing so that pseudify knows how to pseudonymise the data in the database column. We start again with the scalar data structures that are easy to pseudonymise. To do this, you expand the defined database columns ( Column::create() ) in the profile. <?php declare(strict_types=1); namespace Waldhacker\Pseudify\Profiles; use Faker\Provider\Person; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Processor\Processing\DataProcessing; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Processor\Processing\Pseudonymize\DataManipulatorPreset; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Model\Pseudonymize\Column; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Model\Pseudonymize\TableDefinition; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Pseudonymize\ProfileInterface; class TestPseudonymizeProfile implements ProfileInterface { public function getIdentifier(): string { return 'test-profile'; } public function getTableDefinition(): TableDefinition { $tableDefinition = new TableDefinition(identifier: $this->getIdentifier()); $tableDefinition ->addTable(table: 'wh_user', columns: [ Column::create(identifier: 'username') ->addDataProcessing(dataProcessing: DataManipulatorPreset::scalarData( fakerFormatter: 'userName' )), Column::create(identifier: 'password') ->addDataProcessing(dataProcessing: DataManipulatorPreset::scalarData( fakerFormatter: 'argon2iPassword' )), Column::create(identifier: 'first_name') ->addDataProcessing(dataProcessing: DataManipulatorPreset::scalarData( fakerFormatter: 'firstName', fakerArguments: [Person::GENDER_FEMALE] )), Column::create(identifier: 'last_name') ->addDataProcessing(dataProcessing: DataManipulatorPreset::scalarData( fakerFormatter: 'lastName' )), Column::create(identifier: 'email') ->addDataProcessing(dataProcessing: DataManipulatorPreset::scalarData( fakerFormatter: 'safeEmail' )), Column::create(identifier: 'city') ->addDataProcessing(dataProcessing: DataManipulatorPreset::scalarData( fakerFormatter: 'city' )), ]) // ... ; return $tableDefinition; } } The prepared DataProcessing DataManipulatorPreset::scalarData() is passed to the method addDataProcessing() . Info DataManipulatorPreset::scalarData() already implements everything necessary to pseudonymise simple data structures in the database. To the argument fakerFormatter you pass a formatter provided by the FakerPHP/Faker component or implemented by yourself e.g. email . If a formatter supports arguments, such as with the firstName formatter , these can be passed with the fakerArguments argument. An analysis of the profile now looks like this: $ pseudify pseudify:debug:pseudonymize test-profile Pseudonymization profile "test-profile" ======================================= Pseudonymize data in this tables -------------------------------- ----------------- -------------------------- --------------- ----------------------------- Table column data decoders data manipulators ----------------- -------------------------- --------------- ----------------------------- wh_user username (string) Scalar autogenerated-63db8d8426b5f wh_user password (string) Scalar autogenerated-63db8d8426b64 wh_user first_name (string) Scalar autogenerated-63db8d84270ab wh_user last_name (string) Scalar autogenerated-63db8d84270b0 wh_user email (string) Scalar autogenerated-63db8d84270b1 wh_user city (string) Scalar autogenerated-63db8d84270b2 wh_log ip (string) Scalar wh_log log_message (text) Json wh_log log_data (blob) Hex foo logs wh_user_session session_data (blob) Serialized wh_user_session session_data_json (text) Json wh_meta_data meta_data (blob) Hex<>GzEncode ----------------- -------------------------- --------------- ----------------------------- Under data manipulators you can now see that DataProcessings have been modelled for some columns. The values (e.g. autogenerated-63db8d8426b5f ) are automatically generated by pseudify. If you want to have human-readable identifiers listed for a better overview, you can pass the argument processingIdentifier to the method DataManipulatorPreset::scalarData() . <?php declare(strict_types=1); namespace Waldhacker\Pseudify\Profiles; use Faker\Provider\Person; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Processor\Processing\DataProcessing; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Processor\Processing\Pseudonymize\DataManipulatorPreset; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Model\Pseudonymize\Column; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Model\Pseudonymize\TableDefinition; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Pseudonymize\ProfileInterface; class TestPseudonymizeProfile implements ProfileInterface { public function getIdentifier(): string { return 'test-profile'; } public function getTableDefinition(): TableDefinition { $tableDefinition = new TableDefinition(identifier: $this->getIdentifier()); $tableDefinition ->addTable(table: 'wh_user', columns: [ Column::create(identifier: 'username') ->addDataProcessing(dataProcessing: DataManipulatorPreset::scalarData( fakerFormatter: 'userName', processingIdentifier: 'fake user names' )), Column::create(identifier: 'password') ->addDataProcessing(dataProcessing: DataManipulatorPreset::scalarData( fakerFormatter: 'argon2iPassword', processingIdentifier: 'fake argon2i passwords' )), Column::create(identifier: 'first_name') ->addDataProcessing(dataProcessing: DataManipulatorPreset::scalarData( fakerFormatter: 'firstName', fakerArguments: [Person::GENDER_FEMALE], processingIdentifier: 'fake female first names' )), Column::create(identifier: 'last_name') ->addDataProcessing(dataProcessing: DataManipulatorPreset::scalarData( fakerFormatter: 'lastName', processingIdentifier: 'fake last names' )), Column::create(identifier: 'email') ->addDataProcessing(dataProcessing: DataManipulatorPreset::scalarData( fakerFormatter: 'safeEmail', processingIdentifier: 'fake safe email addresses' )), Column::create(identifier: 'city') ->addDataProcessing(dataProcessing: DataManipulatorPreset::scalarData( fakerFormatter: 'city', processingIdentifier: 'fake citiy names' )), ]) // ... ; return $tableDefinition; } } $ pseudify pseudify:debug:pseudonymize test-profile Pseudonymization profile "test-profile" ======================================= Pseudonymize data in this tables -------------------------------- ----------------- -------------------------- --------------- --------------------------- Table column data decoders data manipulators ----------------- -------------------------- --------------- --------------------------- wh_user username (string) Scalar fake user names wh_user password (string) Scalar fake argon2i passwords wh_user first_name (string) Scalar fake female first names wh_user last_name (string) Scalar fake last names wh_user email (string) Scalar fake safe email addresses wh_user city (string) Scalar fake citiy names wh_log ip (string) Scalar wh_log log_message (text) Json wh_log log_data (blob) Hex foo logs wh_user_session session_data (blob) Serialized wh_user_session session_data_json (text) Json wh_meta_data meta_data (blob) Hex<>GzEncode ----------------- -------------------------- --------------- ---------------------------
docs.title: Fake scalar data (pseudonymise)

docs.text: In complex data structures, one usually only wants to pseudonymise very specific properties. The data of the database column session_data_json in the table wh_meta_data are suitable as an example. This contains JSON strings such as {"data":{"last_ip": "107.66.23.195"}} . We now want to specifically replace the value of the last_ip property with fake data. For this we define a DataProcessing ( addDataProcessing() ) at the database column ( Column::create() ). In the chapter "Differently encoded database columns" we already mentioned the DataManipulatorContext , which is passed to the anonymous function of a DataProcessing . Various information about the data set to be processed can be obtained through the DataManipulatorContext : $context->getRawData() : The original data of the database column. $context->getDecodedData() : The data of the column after decoding. $context->getDatebaseRow() : Contains the original data of all columns of the row being processed. $context->getProcessedData() : Contains the processed data set by $context->setProcessedData() , otherwise the data of the column after decoding. By using the DataManipulatorContext , the data can also be pseudonymised and passed back to pseudify: With the method fake() , the FakerPHP/Faker component can be initialised to create pseudonyms. With the method setProcessedData() the pseudonymised data structure can be passed back to pseudify. <?php declare(strict_types=1); namespace Waldhacker\Pseudify\Profiles; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Processor\Processing\DataProcessing; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Processor\Processing\Pseudonymize\DataManipulatorContext; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Model\Pseudonymize\Column; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Model\Pseudonymize\TableDefinition; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Pseudonymize\ProfileInterface; class TestPseudonymizeProfile implements ProfileInterface { public function getIdentifier(): string { return 'test-profile'; } public function getTableDefinition(): TableDefinition { $tableDefinition = new TableDefinition(identifier: $this->getIdentifier()); $tableDefinition // ... ->addTable(table: 'wh_user_session', columns: [ // ... Column::create(identifier: 'session_data_json', dataType: Column::DATA_TYPE_JSON) ->addDataProcessing(dataProcessing: new DataProcessing(identifier: 'fake IPv4', processor: function (DataManipulatorContext $context): void { $data = $context->getDecodedData(); $ip = $data['data']['last_ip']; $fakeIp = $context->fake(source: $ip)->ipv4(); $data['data']['last_ip'] = $fakeIp; $context->setProcessedData(processedData: $data); } )), ]) // ... ; return $tableDefinition; } } With $data = $context->getDecodedData(); we get the decoded JSON string in the form of an associative array. With $ip = $data['data']['last_ip']; we get the specific value from the data structure (the IP address) that we want to pseudonymise. The call $context->fake(source: $ip); initialises the faker. The argument source is passed the input value to be pseudonymised, in the example this is the IP address. This is followed by a call to a formatter provided by the FakerPHP/Faker component or self-implemented , e.g. ->ipv4() . Info If a formatter supports arguments, such as with the firstName formatter , the arguments can be passed to the call (e.g. ->firstName(gender: \Faker\Provider\Person::GENDER_FEMALE) ). The pseudonymised data ( $fakeIp ) must then be written back into the data structure ( $data['data']['last_ip'] = $fakeIp; ). With $context->setProcessedData(processedData: $data); the now pseudonymised data structure is passed to pseudify. Pseudify will then encode the data structure again and write it back into the database.
docs.title: Fake non-scalar data (pseudonymise)

docs.text: As already learned in the chapter "Differently encoded database columns" and "Searching differently encoded data" , it can happen that data in database columns are stored in differently encoded form. It can also happen that data in columns are stored in different data formats. Conditions must be used to detect the data format in which the data is stored so that it can be pseudonymised accordingly. In our example, the plaintext data of the database column log_data of the table wh_log is serialised PHP data if the database column log_type contains the value bar . The plaintext data of the database column log_data is in JSON format if the database column log_type contains the value foo . If the database column log_data of the table wh_log contains the value foo , then the data structure looks like this: {"message":"foo text \"ronaldo15\", another \"mcclure.ofelia@example.com\""} ^ ^ username e-mail address If the database column log_data of the table wh_log contains the value bar , then the data structure looks like this: {"message":"bar text \"Block\", another \"georgiana59\""} ^ ^ last name username Using the data from the DataManipulatorContext we can now differentiate which data structure we are dealing with ( 'foo' === $row['log_type'] ) in order to pseudonymise it accordingly. <?php declare(strict_types=1); namespace Waldhacker\Pseudify\Profiles; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Processor\Processing\DataProcessing; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Processor\Processing\Pseudonymize\DataManipulatorContext; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Model\Pseudonymize\Column; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Model\Pseudonymize\TableDefinition; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Pseudonymize\ProfileInterface; class TestPseudonymizeProfile implements ProfileInterface { public function getIdentifier(): string { return 'test-profile'; } public function getTableDefinition(): TableDefinition { $tableDefinition = new TableDefinition(identifier: $this->getIdentifier()); $tableDefinition // ... ->addTable(table: 'wh_log', columns: [ // ... Column::create(identifier: 'log_message', dataType: Column::DATA_TYPE_JSON) ->addDataProcessing(dataProcessing: new DataProcessing(identifier: 'process log messages', processor: function (DataManipulatorContext $context): void { $logMessage = $context->getProcessedData(); preg_match('/^.*(".*").*(".*")$/', $logMessage['message'], $matches); array_shift($matches); $row = $context->getDatebaseRow(); if ('foo' === $row['log_type']) { $userName = trim($matches[0], '"'); $mail = trim($matches[1], '"'); $logMessage['message'] = strtr($logMessage['message'], [ $matches[0] => sprintf('"%s"', $context->fake(source: $userName)->userName()), $matches[1] => sprintf('"%s"', $context->fake(source: $mail)->safeEmail()), ]); } else { $lastName = trim($matches[0], '"'); $userName = trim($matches[1], '"'); $logMessage['message'] = strtr($logMessage['message'], [ $matches[0] => sprintf('"%s"', $context->fake(source: $lastName)->lastName()), $matches[1] => sprintf('"%s"', $context->fake(source: $userName)->userName()), ]); } $context->setProcessedData(processedData: $logMessage); } )), // ... ]) // ... ; return $tableDefinition; } } With $context->setProcessedData(processedData: $logMessage); the pseudonymised data structure is passed to pseudify. Pseudify will now encode the data structure again and write it back into the database.
docs.title: Faking (pseudonymising) different data formats in one database column

docs.text: To preserve data integrity, pseudify is designed to always return the same pseudonym for the same input data during a pseudonymisation run. This means that during the execution of a pseudonymisation using pseudify pseudify:pseudonymize test-profile , all calls to $context->fake(source: 'Stan')->userName() will generate e.g. the pseudonym Klaus each time and not a different one each time. A new pseudonymisation of the original database using pseudify pseudify:pseudonymize test-profile will generate e.g. the pseudonym Roger for all calls to $context->fake(source: 'Stan')->userName() each time and not Klaus as in the first pseudonymisation run. This ensures two things: Within a pseudonymisation run, the same original data is always replaced with the same pseudonym. (The value "Stan" from Table 1 and Table 2 is replaced with "Klaus" in Table 1 and Table 2). Between different pseudonymisation runs, the same original data generate different pseudonyms. (In the first pseudonymisation, the value "Stan" from Table 1 and Table 2 is replaced with "Klaus" in both tables, in the second pseudonymisation, the value "Stan" from Table 1 and Table 2 is replaced with the value "Roger" in both tables, and so on). If for some reason you want to change this behaviour, you can add the parameter scope to the method $context->fake() . With this parameter you can instruct pseudify to create different pseudonyms per scope for the same input data. Example: $context->fake(source: 'Stan')->userName() returns Greg $context->fake(source: 'Stan', scope: 'something_else')->userName() returns Terry $context->fake(source: 'Stan')->userName() returns Greg $context->fake(source: 'Stan', scope: 'something_else')->userName() returns Terry $context->fake(source: 'Terry')->userName() returns Brian $context->fake(source: 'Terry', scope: 'something_else')->userName() returns Lewis Info Calls of $context->fake() create identical pseudonyms based on the following variables : same source data same formatter same formatter arguments same scope same APP_SECRET This applies within one pseudonymisation run. A new pseudonymisation run will form other pseudonyms with the same variables.
docs.title: Use different pseudonyms for the same input data

docs.text: Just before pseudify writes the pseudonymised data back to the database, the life cycle method is called . This can be defined at a database column ( Column::create() ). <?php declare(strict_types=1); namespace Waldhacker\Pseudify\Profiles; use Doctrine\DBAL\Query\QueryBuilder; use Doctrine\DBAL\Schema\Column as DoctrineColumn; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Model\Pseudonymize\Column; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Model\Pseudonymize\TableDefinition; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Model\Pseudonymize\Table; use Waldhacker\Pseudify\Core\Profile\Pseudonymize\ProfileInterface; class TestPseudonymizeProfile implements ProfileInterface { public function getIdentifier(): string { return 'test-profile'; } public function getTableDefinition(): TableDefinition { $tableDefinition = new TableDefinition(identifier: $this->getIdentifier()); $tableDefinition // ... ->addTable(table: 'wh_log', columns: [ Column::create(identifier: 'log_message') // ... ->onBeforeUpdateData(onBeforeUpdateData: function (QueryBuilder $queryBuilder, Table $table, Column $column, DoctrineColumn $columnInfo, mixed $originalData, mixed $processedData, array $databaseRow): void { // ... }), // ... ]) // ... ; return $tableDefinition; } } In this callback, you have access to all important objects and data in order to be able to carry out data manipulations in some wild scenarios: $originalData : The original data in the database, which will be replaced immediately. $processedData : The pseudonymised data, which will be written immediately. $databaseRow : The entire original data set $queryBuilder : The Query Builder instance used to write the data $table : The pseudify table instance modelled by you $column : The pseudify column instance modelled by you $columnInfo : The doctrine Column instance with useful technical information about the database column. If you want to manipulate something before updating the data, this is possible using the $queryBuilder instance. Changing the other objects and data will have no effect.
docs.title: The onBeforeUpdateData() life cycle method

docs.text: A "Pseudonymizer Profile" can be executed with the command pseudify:pseudonymize <profile-name> . After the pseudonymisation, the word done is displayed. $ pseudify pseudify:pseudonymize test-profile done
docs.title: Apply a "Pseudonymizer Profile"

docs.text: You can test your profile without overwriting the data in the database. With the parameter --dry-run all SQL statements are listed that pseudify would execute. pseudify pseudify:pseudonymize test-profile --dry-run UPDATE `wh_user` SET `username` = :dcValue1:'tavares.satterfield' WHERE `username` = :dcValue2:'karl13' UPDATE `wh_user` SET `password` = :dcValue1:'$argon2i$v=19$m=8,t=1,p=1$WUlUVS9HOW1PN1dXd1pyeg$GTKopoFTAlCufz2QS/c/DzcaLKm/6xMo80ZNiph48Q4' WHERE `password` = :dcValue2:'$argon2i$v=19$m=8,t=1,p=1$amo3Z28zNTlwZG84TG1YZg$1Ka95oewxn3xs/jLrTN0R9lhIxtNnQynBFRdE/70cAQ' UPDATE `wh_user` SET `first_name` = :dcValue1:'Annalise' WHERE `first_name` = WHERE `username` = :dcValue2:'howell.damien' UPDATE `wh_user` SET `password` = :dcValue1:'$argon2i$v=19$m=8,t=1,p=1$UG5xNENBektsOTk3bmpyTw$BAj6FBUDYe2t6QnW14qC+5S22gsI0iVLWawob1YiXKo' WHERE `password` WHERE `log_message` = :dcValue2:'{"message":"bar text \\"Homenick\\", another \\"cyril06\\""}' UPDATE `wh_user_session` SET `session_data` = `wh_user_session` SET `session_data_json` = :dcValue1:'{"data":{"last_ip":"6f5a:517a:963e:86fd:d691:c2a9:fe4f:4ea7"}}' WHERE `session_data_json` = :dcValue2:'{"data":{"last_ip":"244.166.32.78"}}' UPDATE `wh_user_session` SET `session_data` = :dcValue1:'a:1:{s:7:"last_ip";s:39:"973a:942c:b9c7:d128:f8d4:c4cf:3d16:d168";}' WHERE `session_data` = :dcValue1:'{"data":{"last_ip":"973a:942c:b9c7:d128:f8d4:c4cf:3d16:d168"}}' WHERE `session_data_json` = :dcValue2:'{"data":{"last_ip":"1321:57fc:460b:d4d0:d83f:c200:4b:f1c8"}}' UPDATE `wh_user_session` SET `session_data` = :dcValue1:'a:1:{s:7:"last_ip";s:13:"78.176.79.162";}' WHERE `session_data` = :dcValue2:'a:1:{s:7:"last_ip";s:14:"197.110.248.18";}' UPDATE `wh_user_session` SET `session_data_json` = :dcValue1:'{"data":{"last_ip":"78.176.79.162"}}' WHERE `session_data_json` = :dcValue2:'{"data":{"last_ip":"197.110.248.18"}}' UPDATE `wh_meta_data` SET `meta_data` = :dcValue1:'' WHERE `meta_data` = :dcValue2:'' UPDATE `wh_meta_data` SET `meta_data` = :dcValue1:'' WHERE `meta_data` = :dcValue2:'' UPDATE `wh_meta_data` SET `meta_data` = :dcValue1:'' WHERE `meta_data` = :dcValue2:'' UPDATE `wh_meta_data` SET `meta_data` = :dcValue1:'' WHERE `meta_data` = :dcValue2:'' UPDATE `wh_meta_data` SET `meta_data` = :dcValue1:'' WHERE `meta_data` = :dcValue2:'' Note The original data and the pseudonymised data are not shown one-to-one. Valid SQL of the first line should be UPDATE wh_user SET username = 'tavares.satterfield' WHERE username = 'karl13' . However, --dry-run additionally lists the name of the internally used placeholder (e.g. :dcValue1: , :dcValue2: ...) before the data, which can simplify debugging.
docs.title: dry run

erzeugen gleiche Pseudonyme über alle Datenbankspalten hinweg 🎉 Analysiere und pseudonymisiere einfach enkodierte Daten 🎉 Analysiere und pseudonymisiere mehrfach enkodierte Daten 🎉 Analysiere und docs.text: Über das Projekt Das Projekt wurde umgesetzt von Ralf Zimmermann , ermöglicht durch die waldhacker UG (haftungsbeschränkt) und gefördert durch das Bundesministerium für Bildung und Forschung . Vielen Dank auch an den Prototype Fund und die Open Knowledge Foundation Deutschland e.V. für die Unterstützung!

docs.text: Entwicklung Website Der Quellcode der Webseite befindet sich im Repository pseudify-page . Um die Webseite zu entwickeln, wird das Programm ddev benötigt. Starten der Webseite ddev start ddev launch Erstellen der Webseite # 0.1 = current version ddev exec ../build/build.sh 0.1 Core Der Quellcode von pseudify befindet sich im Repository pseudify-core . Um pseudify zu entwickeln wird das Programm ddev benötigt. Das PHAR Archiv erstellen docker run -it -v $(pwd):/data --workdir=/data \ php:8.1-cli-alpine \ sh -c '\ apk update \ && apk add bash rsync \ && /bin/bash -c "build/build-phar.sh" \ && chown -R '$(id -u)':'$(id -g)' .build/ \ ' Das docker image bauen Dieser Schritt benötigt als Vorarbeit die Ausführung der Befehle unter "Das PHAR Archiv erstellen". ./build/build-docker.sh Erstellen von pseudify ddev start ddev exec composer install docker run -it -v $(pwd)/build/development/userdata/:/app -u $(id -u):$(id -g) \ composer create-project waldhacker/pseudify-profile-templates --stability=dev --remove-vcs cp build/development/userdata/pseudify-profile-templates/tests/mariadb/10.5/.env build/development/userdata/pseudify-profile-templates/.env ddev exec 'rm -f ~/.pgpass ~/.my.cnf && mariadb -h mariadb_10_5 -uroot -p"pseudify(!)w4ldh4ck3r" pseudify_utf8mb4 < ../build/development/userdata/pseudify-profile-templates/tests/mariadb/10.5/pseudify_utf8mb4.sql' ddev exec bin/pseudify pseudify:debug:table_schema
docs.title: Entwicklung
